Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2011 12:33PM 3littlegirls wrote: I had only read the first page when I posted.  I have never had a PET scan either. Here in Canada they do bone scans and CT scans.  I think it is probably cheaper. Not sure.  As for your path report. I am surprised it was not given to you. You can go to your hospital and ask for all your reports and they will either mail them to you or you can pick them up. If you are part of the Royal Bank they have a thing called Best Doctors.  They will retest your tumors and go over all your blood work and scan results and then it is all sent to a Dr (who has been appointed through other Dr's voting on who they would go to if they had Breast Cancer).  He/She will respond with a full report and you can ask specific questions.

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2013 03:05AM 3littlegirls wrote: I think that what they are saying is once it has spread to other places (mets) it doesn't matter how early they detect it. Unless it is one met and tey can blast it.  What matters is how you respond to treatment/s. So yes some can live a long time and may get to NED.  That has nothing to do with how early they catch it but how well the tumours respond to the treatment options. That being said it does tend to show that those living with only bone mets can manage it longer then those with soft tissue involvement. Mind you everyone responds differently, no matter where the involvement.  This disease is so complicated.   I hope that helps.
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2013 04:46PM 3littlegirls wrote: Hi, I am actually doing it at the moment. Well not this moment ;)  I started a little over a month ago.  I do local hyperthermia the day after I do chemo (Abraxane) which is every week for 3 and then one off.  On my week off I do full body hyperthermia.  I just had my 3 month scan and it has shown major reduction in my liver tumours.  My largest tumour which was the only one growing when I had to start chemo went from 5.2 cm down to 3.5cm.  My Onc thinks that it is actually even smaller but that the scar tissue is still showing on the scan. Apparently they can't tell the difference. So I am pretty happy with that report.  I am doing it in Fort Langley, BC, Canada.

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2013 05:31PM 3littlegirls wrote: Health Canada was watching over the treatments in Fort Langley and just gave it's approval about 6-7 months ago. I also did it in Tijuana a couple of years ago. I did the version where they heat your blood and then pump it back into you.  I didn't get any shrinkage with that one. Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2012 12:30AM 3littlegirls wrote: learnin it sounds like you had a very inexperienced ND.  No one can gaurentee anything. Especially in this nasty world of cancer.  I did not do anything before my diagnoses.  I was a eat whatever drink (yes please)  and pretty happy go lucky.  Once I was diagnosed I basically went to Chapters and bought every book on cancer I could find. As well as surfeing the net until I basically got sick of reading up on it. About a year and a half.  For me it made sense and I felt like I was heading down the right path.  I was working hard to get to NED. Not a drop of sugar for over a year.  I was skinny skinny!  I went to Mexico and was told my cholesterol was too low.  Who knew that could be an issue.  Anyway they revamped my diet to include meat again. Vegans eat a lot of beans and lentils high in copper which supplies new blood vessel growth to the tumours.  Anyway that is sort of how I came about this whole thing.   Amy triple neg patients often respond really well to high dose Vit C.  You might want to have a look into it.  If you have any specific questions. My ND is more then happy to answer them. He knows a lot fo people can't afford to see an ND and he is more then happy to help answer any questions.  Not trying to sell him on you just thought if you were curious.  That goes for everyone else. Even if they are based on doubt. I don't mind.   And yes I am also happy that this didn't turn into a mud sling. :)
Posts.Title: Choices made in the face of fear Chickadee 3littlegirls

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2012 07:04PM 3littlegirls wrote: Thanks ladies.  As it turns out I did not go.  For whatever reason I could not fall alsepp last night.  I took my sleep drugs plus Melatonin and proceded to lay in bed all night thinking WTH!  So this morning I was exhausted and didn't think it was a wise idea to go boarding and be that whiped. No idea why that happened.  Guess it wasn't in the cards. If I feel fine Tuesday I will go then. I spoke with a Dr (good friend but couldn't get a hold of him till after I posted)) last night and he did say to be careful that it can flip the port or kink the tubes if I did any superman moves down the hill. Which he has seen me do lol.  Just wanted to share that so others reading are aware.  He is an anesthesiologist and has had to remove ports due to infections etc and he said even after the first month they come out easy so they are not sitting solid under the skin.  After a few months a layer of skin grows around it and keeps it snug. Medically he would not advise it but he said if it were him he would go.  Then he said he would kick my butt if I did anything crazy and messed it up.  Yes I do thrive on sports.  It's how I cope.  I have been cooped up with the last round of Paclitaxol kicking my butt then port and 4 weeks of company so it is time for me to get out and burn some calorise and energy. Hoping without the steroids I will have more energy. Penny I hope you do dust it off.  It will give your spirit a good lift. Nothing like being outdoors.  Thanks for all your feedback.

Posts.Content: Jun 21, 2011 01:47AM 3littlegirls wrote: HI,  I am so sorry for what you are going through. I just wanted to add I have liver mets they were at innumerable and my ND told me to put castor oil over the area that my liver is.  If you put it on a cloth and then cover it with serane wrap it is suppose to help pull the toxins from your liver. This might help take some of the burden off your liver, so it can repair itself. And it's cheap so why not.  You might also try an infra red sauna.  They help you sweat out all the toxins from chemo.  I hope you can enjoy the break from chemo and build up your strength.  I just came back from the Angeles hospital in Tijuana.  I won't know if things are working or not but I feel a lot more energetic and the treatments they do build up your immune system and train it to fight the cancer by harvesting your white cells and feeding them the cancer info, as well as a bunch of other treatments.  If you are interested I can send you the info on it.  They do what is called Functional Oncology.   I don't want to be annoying. Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2012 07:14PM 3littlegirls wrote: I wasn't going to chime in but I think one point that hasn't been made is this one.  All the alternative therapies and "drugs" haven't been tested by the FDA or anyone is because they can't be patented.  No patent, no money, no funding, no interest.  DCA as some of you know used to be used in hospitals for brain cancer.  It was pulled. Not because it didn't work but for some unknown reason.  My ND has the stuff and has been giving it to one of his brain cancer patients.  He was seeing progression on every scan since Sept.  He started DCA 4 weeks ago and his last scan showed 25% regression. His own Onc told him that is the only drug that will shrink his tumour.  But he as an Onc can not perscribe it.  High dose Vit C I can give you countless success stories as well as fails.  Our cancers are all different and we all know we all respond differently.  Vit C can work just as well as any other chemo.  The only difference is it doesn't leave you bald, chemo brainned and sick.  It boost energy, repairs veins and shrinks tumours.  No FDA is going to approve it because there is no money to be made off of it.  Sadly this IS how our system works.  I have been doing the "alternative"way as well as the "western" way and I feel great.  I have no symptoms or pain.  I probably have more energy then most "healthy" people and am still on Tamoxifen coming up on 2 years.  I don't know for sure if it is the Quercetin or not.  But my ND says that it is suppose to help stop the tumours from building their little sub pumps and spitting out the drugs (how they build resistance).  I can't prove what is working but I know I will not give up anything to see which one it is.   We all chose to do what is right for ourselves but I find it annoying to be judged for doing so.   I am not scared I am fighting with all the weapons I can.  I have 3 kids relying on me to be around as long as I can.  I've reserched my treatments well and I have also been to Mexico for treatment.  I didn't get any shrinkage but I came back with more energy then I had in years.  The dendritic vaccine I had down there almost 2 years ago is now part of a clinical trial. So in some ways they are just ahead of the game.  If you look at Germany they have the highest rates of remission then any other part of the world.  Because they have integrated the two.  We need to follow suit.  There that is my 2 cents! :)

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2012 01:33AM 3littlegirls wrote: To answer your question in a simple way Chickadee, by law you can't patent anything natural. So Vit C can not have a patent. If you don't own the patent you can't make crazy money off of it.  So pharmaceuticals are not interested in spending millions of dollars investigating and running trials on something they will not make money off of.  They are a business and they are looking for ways to make a profit.  Selling natural agents does not even come close to what they make.  I do think there are people hard at work looking for the cure. I don't buy into the whole the cure is out there and they are hiding it.  I don't think natural agents can save us but I do think they have their place in keeping my butt on this side of the dirt a little longer then if I didn't use them.  A lot of places in Europe use Mistletoe/Iscador as part of there conventional treatment.  It can be used to inhance the effects of chemo. Thereforer they don't have to administer as much chemo to their patient to get the same results. Less toxic and costs less.  As well it works to boost your white cell count. Therefore ommitting the need for Neulasta.  Which they are discovereing might actually might not be that good for us.  Same as the bone biophosphates.  Which have all gone through rigorous testing.  They are now discovering that long term they in fact make your bones brittle. Not strengthening them like they once thought.  Anyway I could go on and on.  There is no right way unfortunately.  Or at least they haven't put all the pieces together.  Hopefully in our life time or at least our kids lives.  I wish we could all get out of this mess and go back to our old lives.  I think as a collective we are a pretty powerful group with a voice.  I wish if something was tried in one counrty it would be good enough for other countries to follow suit.  I think a lot of money is wasted testing it in all these different countries to get the same results.  They need to mandate certain guidlines and if those guidlines are met then the info collected from one source should be good enough.  It would help us get somewhere.  As well they need to regulate Naturopaths.  Right now anyone can pretend to be one.  So yes there are a lot of quacks out there preying on the sick. If they regulated it, it would be a huge step forward. K hope this helped somewhat.  Sorry it is late and I hope I am making sense.
Posts.Title: Choices made in the face of fear Chickadee 3littlegirls

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2012 08:20PM 3littlegirls wrote: No alternative practioner has offered me a cure.  They are trying to keep my body strong and in peak performance to keep the tumours at bay.  With a strong immune system and trying to keep my body low in sugar and more alkaline it is less hospitible for the cancer to grow.  It's like trying to grow a cabbage in poor soil.  If I ate an acid based, high fat high sugar diet it makes sence to me the tumours would grow happily.  I am just trying to do what makes sense to me.  I guess us alties have felt snipped at a ot on here and so don't normally open up.  I see a Naturopathic Oncologist so he is trained and legit.  He has never said cure and he does believe that chemo has it's place.  I love my Onc but I only see him once every 4 months.  I am in Canada and we have free health care so I don't need to pay for my "western" treatments.   And for the record I have been burned by the health care system but don't feel that it would of changed my desire to seek a Naturopathic Oncologist.  It has only made me more of an advocate and incharge of my own health.  Perhps if they had caught it early enough I may not have felt the need. But unfortunately that is not the case.    I am glad we are having this discussion and hope it makes people a little less judgemental on both sides of this discussion. I think we all need hope to cope!  My hope is to ride this mess out.  I wish the same for everyone on here.

He loves them but he doens't enjoy parenting like I do.  Think when they are older he will but I am so worried about how well he will raise and love them when I am gone.   I read an article that I plan on doing as well. It is ask a few girlfriends to step up when I am gone.  This guy who had cancer picked 3 of his friends to become involved with his kids. He picked each one because they had values/interests he liked and wanted to bestow on his kids. They started coming around and becoming involved with his kids while he was still battling cancer. So if he did die it wouldn't be such a transition for his kids. He ended up living (lucky bum) but the men continued on in their lives.  It was a Readers Digest story.  Anyway it stuck. I think I will try and get some of my girlfriends onboard. I know they probably will anyway.  I am blessed with amazing friends.
Posts.Title: No, you don't understand... Stormynyte Reneepals

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2011 12:28AM 3littlegirls wrote: I am so so so so sorry you, your wife and children are having to go through this horrible thing. It is soo unfair and I wish I could help ease the pain and just change everything for you and all of us suffering. Especially so close to Christmas. It is just plain unfair and I hate it. Your story has brought me to tears.  I wish we could step through the computer into your house and help.   I hope she isn't in any pain and that you have time to make some more wonderful memories.  I will pray for your family and for a miracle. It is Christmas after all.   Hugs to you and your family.
